content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
 Developers Before I go into my review I need to tell you all some things. To put this in the nicest way possible, the developers are an unprofessional, and hypocritical team of failures. If you go into the forums or look at their facebook page you will notice that any negativity against them will result in a "professional" and instant lash towards you. In the community forums you will notice that they have whined about negativity towards their "finished game". You will also notice that they say they will listen and answer everyone who has a question. I have asked a couple of questions and got no answers from the developers. Only answers from other community members telling me that they do not answer anyone. This game has been abandoned for quite some time and left with bugs and barely any gameplay to justify the price. As far as we're all concerned, they're back to just fix the bugs, add a "sandbox" mode and then throw their hands up and be done with it.  I have been banned from the forums yesterday after talking about a promising sounding new police simulator called 'Police 10-13'. Apparently they can't answer questions, but do visit the forums frequently to find an excuse to ban people that don't hold their game in high regards. To be fair, part of what I talked about was how the developers making 10-13 are making themselves look and I quote "like idiots" because there are multiple things they are doing that professionals wouldn't do. And the ban is fair according to the rules. In short, I'm iffy about it like I should be after this farce. Only time will tell and I am still excited to see the news and its development.  With this said about the developers, please be very cautious about their new project 'CTU' (Counter Terrorism Unit). These developers are childish and are untrustworthy.  Story The only story there is is a quick intro scene saying that your father was great at being a police officer. After that you're thrown in with a pop up text tutorial and you figure out the rest. Gameplay While it's clearly clunky and buggy, it is fun for a while. I put in 8 hours before getting very bored. I went back into the game to see if anything was changed or added despite what people said just to make sure, and nothing has been done. All there is is just a few cars you unlock by entering 'codes'. Your duties will differ. You will give chase on foot, get into gunfights, set up speedometers, arrest drunks and those that have harmed others and sometimes break and enter homes that have been reported to have someone armed and dangerous. It's realistic to a very small degree and has potential. Before the game was released, it had a different name and had a lot more going in (more buildings, looked much more polished, basically everything that makes a game look good to hype it up in the beginning). If all that was there it would be really good. Sound Voice acting is terrible, music is very dull and on repeat, guns don't sound right etc. The sound isn't terrible, but it isn't good. And all of the talking past the introduction is silent and through text. Graphics  The graphics are basically a more polished GTA: San Andreas. Lighting is better and textures are smoother but not by much. It looks like one of the later PS2 games. Overall It's good in short bursts if you don't care for too much content but the bugs will irritate you enough to not want to play. With Police 10-13 planning on coming sometime in 2016 I would hold off. And there are other simulators much better than this one. The GTA IV police mod is the best one and there's an older and sillier simulation that feels complete as well called Police Force if you don't want to wait. But this "simulator" is worth $5 at best and even real police officers are voicing how bad this is. Get a better simulator or hold off for Police 10-13. Small Immediate Edit I've had this review written out for quite some time and could not post it up until now and have no idea why and so I saved it and waited. Now that I've finally been able to post it, please spread the word about not getting this game at any price. I have never fallen victim to bad developers as I'm usually good about asking for opinions and looking at whether the business is professional as well up until now. And again, it isn't because I was banned from the forums. I have nothing personal against that. Just their empty promises, lack of news and refusal to keep an open mind and accept the fact that not everyone will be happy and they screwed up badly is why I am bashing them directly. I hope my review helps and happy gaming!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I hadn't purchased a game for full price in a long while, but was itching to try this one after watching Robbaz's (YouTuber) playthrough for it. I saw that it was on sale via the Humbebundle store for $14.99, so I purchased it there.The game is really fun, and if you like police simulators at all, you will enjoy this game - I will continue to play it and see how it develops. Unfortunately, however, I have to leave this at a "do not recommend," because I feel very disappointed at the product I was presented with. The simplest way for me to have given Enforcer a "thumbs up," would be for the developers to have this labelled as an early access/beta game. As an avid game reviewer, I CANNOT support this type of presentation. I have a fairly massive backlog of games in my library left to review (on top of my backlog of games to play), but I decided to bump this up to the very top, because I want as many people to avoid making the mistake I made in buying this game AND believing it to be a final, finished product. I went ahead and tried it out despite many of the negative reviews, but I implore everyone and anyone interested to wait to see whether or not the game actually develops further.Because quite obviously, this is a largely unfinished, barebones product. It both plays and feels like an early access game, and I would know, since I had a pretty potent early access game phase. Unlike the cesspool that is Starbound, I sincerely hope that the developers for Enforcer continue to work on the game, as it definitely has a lot of potential. Now, on to the meat of the review.The aesthetics are good, the detail in the environment and character models are decent. The rain effects are pretty weak, and there the vehicle damage is insignificant. There seems to be a very low pool of character models, with the main difference being the color of their outfits. The vehicle pool is also considerably tiny, and you will notice this very quickly. The sounds and music are average, but I prefer to play my own instead. While in your police cruiser, there will be chatter over the radio, but (again) that pool appears to also be small, so you will notice repetitions within the first hour of playing. The controls may take a bit of effort to get used to - there is a pop-up help menu right when you begin, and a super quick tutorial after you select your character sex and name. The help menu also provides descriptions for most of the things you can currently do in the world, and I strongly recommend you take a look through everything to properly orient yourself in the Enforcer world. The learning curve is minimal to moderate, depending on your experience with police simulators. You can play the game on normal or realistic mode, the latter having permanent death and more rapid/frequent missions for you to do. I've played this game quite a bit and enjoyed it a lot, however, many of the game elements show the unpolished quality common in early access game builds. For example, the AI is very basic, and many times you might ask a car to pull over, only to have them rear-end another car. Of course, the sloppiness of the AI will fool you, as this event will NOT constitute as an offence of any sort (at least on top of whatever offence that particular NPC might already have committed). I've seen a car speed through a red light and drive straight into a civilian crossing the street (not hurting the walker in any way, oddly enough) and - after pulling him over - the only recorded offence was speeding. When you pull over vehicles - you can do so by toggling your cruiser's warning siren, or calling out on foot - you will be given a few options like: apply breathalyzer, write ticket, and check license and registration (this will show you any offences the driver has committed). Something I don't really like about the latter feature is that you can set up traffic cones to create a roadblock, then go through an endless lineup of cars and spam the "check license and registration" option. Even if the car had been speeding blocks away from you, you will magically know that they were speeding with your omniscient police powers. Note, that this is also a pretty cheap way to farm police points, which contribute to your police ranking (the higher your ranking, the more money you make after each shift, and the larger the variety of missions available to you).After pulling people over, you can arrest drunk drivers and either put them in your squadcar (to take them to the police station), walk them to the station, or call a police van. Calling a police van, ambulance, or tow truck will bring you to a loading-type screen, and everything will occur behind-the-scenes, then bring you back to real-time. I don't mind this, considering how quickly you can pull over and check cars. Some NPCs might flee if you ask then to step out of the vehicle, and a quick taser shot will make them complaint again. Abusing your power (shooting them again with the taser, or even using your pistol) will cause considerable penalties to your police score. One thing that really irritates me about this game is that it seems to only register "lethal force" as acceptable if the NPC shoots at you first. So, they can pull out and aim a gun at you, but until they shoot, you best use a taser, or worse - wait. NPCs commonly drop their weapons after taking one or two shots, and you MUST arrest them after this, or incur a penalty. I tried using a taser just to make sure they would remain complaint after the criminal dropped his gun, but received a heavy penalty for power abuse (annoyed me quite a bit). I also had a scenario where 2 NPCs were shooting at me (I still used only my pistol and not my sub-machinegun) - I killed the first person, and received a penalty for killing the second person because he hadn't fired at me yet. The crime/consequence algorithms can use a lot of refinement. It takes about two shots for you to die/be hospitalized, and the only way to heal is to sleep in your bed, or pay a fee at the hospital. Respawning (if you are playing normal) results in a considerable penalty to your police score.I've taken a screenshot of a parked car hovering in the air, stuck in an odd position. I gave it a ticket and towed it - scoring some points. As I continued playing, I was disappointed to see so many cars randomly stuck in the air, at different elevations. Clearly, the bugginess throughout the game should speak volumes regarding its quality as a finished product. You are the ONLY police officer in the small city (map is split into grids, and you can travel to each one by driving - or teleport whenever you leave your house).There are three meters you must take care of - energy, hunger, and stress, You can eat while you are on duty (you must select "on duty" in your closet at home to start your shift), but you cannot sleep or recover stress. After enough time has passed, you will be able to end your shift by going to the police station and selecting that option. You can, however, continue to work, but your gauges will continue to fall. To fill these, you can sleep at home or eat at any place that sells food (you pay $5 when you interact with your fridge). Stress is recovered by going out with your friends or family, and each social call costs 4h of gametime. While off duty, you have a meter that will show you how long you can stay off for, and continuing to stay off duty after your time is up will cause you to progressively lose police points (you can get fired/lose the game if it falls low enough). When you go for social calls, it will take you to a loading scene with a picture of whoever you decided to spend time with. A much more effective way (as of now) seems to be to buy a television in your house (use the online store on your laptop) and repeatedly watch tv. Doing so not only raises your stress, but also fills some of your energy (allowing you to skip sleeping in bed).

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I regret having to give this game a thumbs down, because I really do think it could have been something. In it's current state, it isn't worth the $20 price tag. The game lacks content and gets boring real fast. At this moment, there is only ONE developer working on this game. In the discussion threads, the developer explains that to him, this game is complete, and basically everything from now on is just icing on the cake...WOW... This game is basically an alpha...if that. I understand the whole small team, low budget thing, but to say this game is, in any way complete, is just plain crazy. PROS:+Can be entertaining in small bursts.+Sandbox+The game does have potential (maybe not anymore, but it did).+It has an aspect of realism to it.+The updates are free (as they should be), and the developer stated he didn't want DLCs.+Developers respond to you if you ask a question or comment on something.+Pretty cool customization of your police unit. You can also purchase things like a new flatscreen or a couch for your house with your hard earned cash, which is sweet.CONS:-Bugs/Glitches (apparently not enough to be game breaking as the game is completed--spoken by developer)-Stiff movement system for driving and on-foot. Frustrating controls.-Poor animations.-GTA 3 graphics.-Not enough content to warrant a $20 price tag. It needs more missions/guns/cars/skins/buildings/everything.I really wish this game had more fans and a workshop, because that would change things. More content, better graphics/animations, more skins/customization, would add to the longevity of the game. At the state that this game is in, I cannot recommend this title.Verdict: 5/10

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This is clearly a game with a relitively low budget, but still is a very fun police simulator and, in my opinion, worth the money. In this review I will assess the positives and negatives, explain some of the features and finally give my verdict on the game.Positives: - Variety of different missions (passive and direct).- 7 regions to explore.- On and Off Duty modes.- Level up / Ranking system in the police force.- Can interact with every NPC civilian.- Police cars have warning sirens, full sirens, and lightbars that can be customised.- Variety of clothing and vehicle paintjobs.- Realistic feel of policing.- Can storm buildings, make civilians surrender, stop fleeing vehicles by hitting them with yours.- Has an easy and hard mode.Negatives:- At the time of its release, it is quite buggy.- When an ambulance / police transport / tow truck is called, they are not actually seen.- Car physics are not very realistic.- You get reduced career points for actions such as breaking down doors even if there is a criminal inside.- You are the only patrol officer in the game.- Fleeing NPCs act as if they were not being chased if they get clear of you a few metres, then run again when you get close.- Limited things to do Off Duty.- Does not have a very comrehensive help / controls screen.PLEASE NOTE MANY OF THE ABOVE WILL MOST LIKELY BE IMPROVED / FIXED AS THE GAME DEVELOPS!Suggestions:- Could have custom loadouts (e.g. different weapons).- Could call backup such as a SWAT team.- When the player reaches a high rank, they could command other officers.- Needs more vehicles and Off Duty activities (could maybe respond to specific emergencies).Analysis:I am someone who is a big fan of police simulators. Arma 3 Altis Life was great for this, and Enforcer: Police Crime Action is quite similar, only it is single player. You can drive around the town centre looking out for speeders (cars drive around 20mph and around 30mph is considered speeding) and you can pull them over, use the breathalyser or frisk them if you feel it is necessary. On the start of every shift there is a passive mission to complete by the end of the shift, for example setting up a roadblock with cones and checking 6 drivers for faults on their cars. There are also dispatch calls with generous time limits such as finding a person wanted for assaulting passers by. For this you would go and talk to the victims to get a description, then wait until there is intel about where the person was last seen. You would then go to the scene, find the person matching the description, and park up. Normally when you call out for them to stop, they will run off. You can pull out your tazer, and when you get close you fire. After that you can arrest the suspect, take them to the station or call for a transport. You get career points which help you rank up after completing every mission.Off duty mode is really unique, and has a lot of potential. When you have enough money you can buy a car, and you can also customise your home with new furniture. It is also possible to level up your stress level buy going out with friends or your mother, and other people. Instead of actually interacting with your friends or mother, the game teleports you to their house and puts the time forward a few hours, and says that you have spent time with your friends / mother, without you actually seeing anything. Physically doing activities may well be something the developers add in the future. When off duty it is also possible to fill up on food and replenish your energy by sleeping. You have to be careful though as spending too much time off duty will reduce career points.Conclusion:This game as mentioned earlier has obviously been developed on a low budget, but they have made that budget stretch as far as possible. The gameplay is enjoyable even though the graphics and physics are not fantastic. Now it has been released, it is likely that if lots of people buy it and the developers have access to more money, the game will be better optimized, feel more smooth and have some great new features added. That will of course come over time so if anything, the money you put in to buy this game will be an investment, so they can improve it. That said, even before the game is developed further it is still great fun and I can see a lot of hours of gameplay from it.Overall Verdict:I would recommend this game to any fan of police simulators, or anyone who fancies a go at being a police officer. It may at first seem very rough and strange, but believe me, you will probably get used to it just fine.I rate Enforcer: Police Crime Action 7/10 at its current state but it has the potential of being a 8/10 or even 9/10 game.UPDATE: It is now August 2016 with very little development since the review, sadly I would not recommend the game any more.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Great idea, poor execution. An open world sandbox police 'sim' is something i've wanted to play since the likes of Police Quest. And this game pretty much has that idea down. Unfortunately, it's let down by its execution. The graphics and animation are poor, worse than GTA 3. The AI is all but non existant. All NPC criminals either run from you, give up, or stand in one spot and slowly shoot at you. Pathfinding is poor - pedestrians will mindlessly walk into anything blocking their path forever. The physics are poor. Cars don't crash so much as 'stop'. Hitting a tree, building, or even a pedestrian will cause your car to stop on a dime. Other vehicles also have a tendency to fly into the air randomly. If this was early access, I'd say wait and see, but as a fully released title? Sorry, can't reccomend it especially for the price they're asking.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This game at it's current form demands a lot of patience from the person that plays it. Most of the AI is very underdeveloped: pedestrians walking everywhere, stoping for nothing and nobody. The driving in the game is a nightmare. Speed is a relative term at the moment, getting from 20mph to 134mph under a second... and good luck stoping... without immidiate reversing. Missions are quite repetative but so is the life of a police officer... as I would imagine.The time passes real quick. An hour in the game equals to a minute in our life not leaving much space to complete missons without doing 16 hours shifts. The concept of getting hungry, tired and irritated is a great idea, but at the moment they don't have much effect on our character. Ranking up is also a great idea... yet again, doesn't really change much. You are still putting those speeding cameras out, regardless your rank. But enough of the negatives.It's a police simulator! Yes. You are wearing a uniform, you have your police cruiser, which is by the way very nicely detailed, as far as sound and lights go. The weapon mechanics is acceptable and it is fun giving out those tickets for broken lights or  speeding thorugh town to attend a burglary. The developers have a great vision. There is no doubt about it. This game might have been released just a bit too early, but their presence in forums and announcments on up-coming updates is reassuring that buying this game at this price is an investment. Now it is up to us if we are willing to invest and see the development through. I am, because it's exciting to be part of developing a great police simulator.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												My biggest problem with this game is that it feels like a very early access inide game and no where near like the complete product.Firstly the driving mechanics are aweful the controls feel clunky, it feels like driving a tank and you even have to turn off the engine before you are allowed to get out of the car. I don't think they will fix this either because it is one of the core mechanics of the game. Unfortunatly when you do anything it is done through a menu system, for example you call to get a prisoner transport and instead of seeing a car come out and pick up the prisiner you get a screeen shot saying it has been done, this is the same for ambulances, tow trucks ect. The graphics leave a lot to be desired, most of the game looks pretty poor the models look like they came out of a ps1 game, this would not be an issue if the game mechanics were better. Also every citezen looks the same i think there are no more than say 10 character models. The map is split into tiny sections you have to drive through checkpoints to get to different parts of the map, there are so many loading screens in this game for pretty much everything you do.All the above points are things that are core parts of ther game and will probably never be changed/fixed at the time of writing there are many other issues too such as bugs (cars floating in the sky), I feel like the duty time is too short it makes you rush to complete the day, buying yoyur own car is far too expensive compared to how much money you make, you have to get a taxi home because home is too far from the station. Hopefully the modding community will come to the rescue of this game but at the moment i wouldn't recommend this game, ive played played games that cost £4 - £5 that have been more polished  and genrally better games.

Posted: October 24, 2014
												II have been looking for a game like this for a long time but I guess my search will have to go on.Looks like this game is based on Police Mod for GTA IV. It offers you plenty of options what can a good officer do, like patrolling the streets, stopping cars, checking drivers, chasing burglars and vandals.You always play in the sandbox mode and you have to watch your needs (hunger, energy, health). You have to complete some of the missions during duty hours (some of them are optional and randomly generated) but it gets very repetitive very soon. Technical side of the game is a problem. City looks empty and sterile. You see some pedestrians on the streets but they all looks the same (only few types). Driving mechanics is also bad, it feels nothing like any of the GTA games. For the standard price I cannot recommend this game, fair price would be 10 Euro.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												At first this game is amazing, then it gets predictable and repititive. This game is not finished. The developers seem to be working on it. It seems like an early access game.  Part of this game is not really realistic, Like responding to a robbery. They ALWAYS escape on foot. A red circle follows the suspect, even if you have not arrived yet.You do these following things over and over:1)Give parking tickets2)Stop drunk drivers/arrest3)Inspect license and vehicle/ticket4)Go to drug dealers (arrest or shoot)5)Go to hostage situation (arrest or shoot)I would say 7 hours maxes out replay value. I would not spend $20, only $10 (its half off right now) with the condition there is going to be at least 25% more content. Good:This is the only cop game I am aware of.It makes me feel sorry for cops. Realistic mode= one life. If you die, you die. Like being a cop in real life!Fun, until you figure the mechanics out and can predict everything.I got nervous because somebody pulled out their cell phone and I thought it was a gun +++High speed chases during routine traffic stops I ask for somebody to open the door, they do, they have a weapon, I blast them away +++Shooting bad guys (especially on realistic mode) +++Bad:No randomness, easily predicatableYou can't call backup. Bad guys are only activated one at a time if you get in their vincinity Can't see where bullets are coming fromNO BODY ARMOR REALLY??!Promotions are not very valuable at all. Not enough upgradesFun goes downhill fast

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												I wouldn't recommend or even suggest this to anyone. When it came out it had a lot of promise with a dev team that would interect with the players on the forums, addressing bugs and even trying to put in mod support. The content was growing with new vehicles, a reworked and revamped map, and albeit it isn't content, bug fixes.Then it stopped, promises of a huge patch that would add a lot more content and bug fixes was constantly pushed off. They would even start silencing the steam forum of any sort of dissent and eventually the communication stopped. After a bit of a lull they finally came up with a date to expect it. And when the time came, nothing. They addressed it again, gave it another date and once more, nothing.This game showed a lot of promise, considering that there isn't much of a market for Law Enforcement Simulators or even games.  Heck it even had a skeptic like me thinking that they could pull it off.The game in its current state is better then it was when launched, but still retains some of the odd bugs paired with its awkward driving controls and weird AI, you would swear you leapt from the Alpha test to the beginning stages of Beta testing. As for the customization, you can change the skin on your police car and your uniform...and that's it.Although, I may have been gifted this game. I feel nothing but awful for having recieved it knowing that they have willingly spent money on this with the goodness of their heart.If you wish to pursue another Police Simulator, I would recommend that you purchase GTAV and download the LSPDFR mod. The difference is considerable. Especially due to the customization of the LSPDFR Mod that allows you to improve your Law Enforcement experience.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY. This game leaves a lot to be desired and honestly feels like an early release at best. It absolutely is NOT worth the $19.99 at this point in its production and will need many large updates to make it anywhere close to worth its asking price. I will list some pros and cons:Pros:-It's a police simulator and those are hard to come by, if nothing else it's an attempt to deliver a very demanded but rare game format-It's ambitious: There are many features such as buying police cars, living life off work, etc. which are nice on first play-Practial button layout Cons:-Really, really clunky - the car driving and handling may be some of the worst I've ever tried. Sure having features such as having to turn on the engine and the realistic idle movement of drive and reverse are fun in theory, but the steering controls manage to be un and/or late responsive while the gas and reverse are over-responsive. It's horrible. Running and crouching aren't much better.-This game doesn't look pretty. I get that it's not a large studio producing it but if you're going to charge me $20 at least have more than five car and character models in the game-Everyone in this game has a gun. I have done 10 missions and 9/10 ended with the suspect pulling a gun-Shooting controls are very poor - the gun often will not fire the first few shots unless you zoom in, which can lead to getting you killed-Boring mission types - There are a variety of missions and the idea of questioning suspects and searching nearby buildings is a great one, but the tips are only clothing descriptions and all the searches end in you having to gun down a pistol wielding suspect-Simple features such as tow trucks, ambulance calls, and police pick up lack an animation and instead take you to a brief load screen before returning you to where you were witht he action performed - things like this REALLY make it feel like an early access-Whoever developed it is not an English speaker and google translate is not flawless. Many spelling or wording mistakes really prevent it from having a professional, clean fealIn conclusion, don't buy this game. I was incredibly disappointed with this game. I was quite excited that a new police simulator was finally being produced as there are barely any available. Don't get me wrong, I know it is a small project and wouldn't be upset if this were an early release, but I paid a decent price for it for far from a decent product. On the very bare outside it looks similar to LCPDFR, but don't be fooled. This game is far from being worth its asking price and will need some serious updating in the control, mission, and visual department before it comes close its asking price.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
												This game is not a full game. It handles like an early developed mod. It was created for the ground up so as a single developer, this is something to be proud of. However, as a game that claims to be full, it is not even close. There are many areas that are lacking. Many features that were promised that still have yet to show up. The player movement is clunky, car acceleration random and almost uncontrolable, useful customization almost non existant, features that felt like dead ends and were started but never finished. The world feels so empty, and you have such a large area to patrol, I feel like this should be state patrol or sheriff's department. It's so empty. You are the ONLY COP. This is not a complete game. If you're desperate for a police game, ok buy this, but other than that? Don't waist your money. Get GTA IV for $20 and downloand the mod LCPDFR. Its clunky and crashes, but it still feels more complete than this game. You can download additional callouts, bug fixes, custom cars, custom uniforms, different scripts for police AI, the possibilities are endless... Unfortunately this game just falls short. If I knew anything about developing I would totally help this guy out and crank out an awesome and complete game. This game has potential, but a year after launch? Still feels empty and incomplete.In this current state, I would not recommend it.

number of helpful: 27 of 41 people (66%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I want to point out that Enforcer: Police Crime Action is like calling the Half Life Series Scientist: Atoms Destruction Wait. And yet it is still a much better title (and game) Then any of the "Simulation" Games released for the purpose of a quick cash grab.It's simple. You play as a police officer, male or female, and are tasked with the daily routines of being said police officer. You go do a shift by beginning with a mundane mission and will either get interrupted with a more exciting mission or just simply go through the mission and gain points. Points mean you are promoted and get money, thus allowing you to spend it on your house. The closest comparision I have is True Crime: New York City in terms of random missions and being tasked with being a police officer.The game doesn't look impressive, but it get's the job done. It has good character and vehicle animations that allow you to tell what a character is doing and what they plan. The appeal of just going through the daily life of a police officer is a welcome compromise between the hardcore idea of being an officer (Swat series) To the matienince of health and hunger levels (Deadly Premonition).The worst part about this game is that it feels cheap. The love for this game the developers gave to it is clear, and I enjoy the experience thus far, but there are a lot of times where I find cars flipped over for no reason, the camera constantly get's stuck to one position and once someone screams you will hear that scream throughout your shift like that victim is haunting your soul. If given more assets and time, this game could honestly be as good as Euro Truck SImulator in providing for a niche audience.WOULD I RECOMMEND THIS GAME: YESDespite the cheap look this game has, it is a game with a lot of love and detail put into it that already feels like a unique experience. SUGGESTIONS TO DEVS: Focus more on bringing in the social life for the protagionist; I actually felt like this town could be given a lot more history and more characters that you could interact with.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												This game is suprisingly fun for me to play even when not much is happening. The graphics are not the best but they don't take away too much from the gameplay, plus the game came out pretty recently so I'm sure a lot of bugs will be fixed and things added. It's a pretty realistic simulator, as you get rewarded in points for giving out tickets correctly, capturing criminals, and helping out people, and you lose points for arresting innocent people, police abuse, civilian casualties, etc. And as you get points you get promoted, which earns you a larger salary each time you complete a shift, and you can buy items for your house, cars, gas, food, and ammo. You have three meters (stress, energy, and hunger) which you can replenish while off duty or on duty, but you get penalized for staying off duty too long, and you can stay on duty as long as you want as long as you have enough energy. The animations are pretty good for each action like walking, asking questions, hand cuffing, etc. and the only bad part of the animations is the idle animation for you character, as he/she just stands there lik a ragdoll and slightly breathes, and some of the animtion transitions are jumpy but still pretty good. It kinda reminds me of Watch_Dogs except you are the cops and no hacking, but is still fun. You still get some fun out of this despite some bugs and overall apearance, but again, the game is new and I'm sure will be fixed and imporved in time. If you take a look at the news feed on this game, you can see that they are frequently updating and have laid out plans for the future, and I think now might be a good time to get this game so you can get a feel for it and watch it improve, and plus you get a free soundtrack. (If you like that kind of stuff...) I guess you could mess around and just arrest everyone, but i'm not sure if you can "lose" the game yet unless you have realism mode on. Trust me, this game is going to go far, don't let the appearence fool you...

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Okay so the game was good,  There was a time when this game had potential and was going to be good, then the game creators said they were going to Update it in June of 2015 then they said July, then they said Fall of 2015 it is one year later and it has not been updated with what they said they were going to add.Let's get to some of the other bad stuff in this gameEvery Vehicle is being driven illegaly. Some may ask why? Well, because every vehicle in this game don't have licence plates.  And for a Police Simulator to not incorrperate Licence plates it's pretty bad.Let's talk about driving.  HORRIBLE DRIVING IN THIS GAME.  The vehicle speeds up way too quickly.  AI driving is horrible.  And let me tell you about traffic lights.  Cars will stop on green and go on red.  Some traffic lights don't even change to green.  How about pulling over vehicles.Oh this the worst.  If a vehicle is running from you, you actually have to hit them with your vehicle to stop them.  Just parking in front of them after they start running won't stop them.  (Pretty unrealalistic)   (If you don't hit them with your vehicle then you can't open the pull over menu.)So in this game we are seen as the only police officer in town...  While you are playing this game you will not come into contact with another police officer.  Although, if you exit your vehicle you can hear a police radio.  Some YouTubers have said that he/she is so lonley being the only police officer that he/she is playing recordings of a Police Radio.  Honestly I wouldn't blame him/her.  If you are looking for a Good Police Simulation, buy Grand Theft Auto 4 and Install LCPDFR (Just search up LCPDFR.COM) or get Grand Theft Auto 5 and install LSPDFR (Just like before except now it's LSPDFR.COM)  With this mod you can actually run licence plates, pull people out of vehicles and stop someone who is running without hitting them with your vehicle.  And better yet there are actually a lot of other police, so you won't have to worry about being the only police officer in town!To end this there is a new police simulation coming out sometime in the next months called Police 10-13 (https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=252178673) I can tell you that this one will have potential graphics are way better, and they have been working on it for over 3 years so awesome!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												This is a game about being a police officer.I drive with my sirens on and lights flashing, swerving not only between the two lanes, but off the road on either side. I miss ramming other cars on the road...for the most part.I will pull over a car for no reason, and even if I find nothing wrong with it or the driver, I'll still have the car towed, leaving the driver stranded. I get 30 points for every car I have towed, even the ones that don't break any rules.I frisk everybody. If they have a gun, I will arrest them. (Thanks, Obama!)I'll get a call for teenage vandalism, and when I investigate, one of the vandals will start shooting at me. I'll return fire, putting a bullet in their spine. 10/10 would horrifically abuse my power and authority again.Edited to add: The game is made 1000% more fun if you go to options and enter "hohoho" (no quotation marks) in the Secret Codes section. I've seen other reviews complain about vehicle handling. I tried out a police SUV and within two seconds I'd rolled onto the side, and after five seconds (during which the car was still going forward) the car re-righted itself. The janky vehicle handling is a plus in my book.The only thing I'd like to see is some kind of story mode, and/or more variation in the type of cop tasks I can do. (Preferably hilarious ones that let me be more jerkish). And maybe a point to buying fancy furniture? As far as I can tell, the cheapest couch, cheapest TV, and cheapest refrigerator are all I need to satisfy all my needs.

number of helpful: 21 of 31 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												So far this is the best *dedicated police sim* available. If you are a fan of LCPD:FR, you'll love this - it's more refined and less glitchy. It is not without bugs and glitches however, but once you accept that 1. It's the first day of release, 2. It's their first PC game on the market and 3. The team consists of 4 devs you really appreciate the work that has been put into it (especially if you've been following the game since it was first announced like I have).Some feedback I would like to give the devs: 1. Currently certain areas in the roads are buggy, making your car flip at high speed, or just hit invisible objects.2. The cars could be a bit more durable - police cruisers (particularly the Crown Vic) are known for their ability to take a lot of punishment, at current time i lose about 2-4% of vehicle health by going over small bumps at the gas station.3. I'd love to hear more variety in the police radio clips, currently the clips are from the NYPD and as such reference New York locations, it'd be awesome to get voice actors in to record some radio, or at least grab a few more clips.4. Change the hunger animation, or remove it. I don't have a problem with the animation, but it'd be better if it only played once - when the hunger bar drops right down and from then on only having the text notification. I get what it's trying to achieve, and i like it: but at crucial times (foot pursuits, shootouts) it's annoying to have to stop for 3 seconds for the animation to play, leaving you very vulnerable.Some things I'd like to see added in the future: 1. More player customisation (especially some kind of Sheriff / State Trooper uniform)2. More NPC variety 3. An extra civilian car or two (perhaps a charger for about $25,000)4. Perhaps a police motorcyle (and proper uniform of course) for more highway patrol type players. For anyone who has actually read this far, you should definitely get the game if you're into police sims - the devs are very open and actually listen to our feedback, so give it a play and tell them (constructively) what you think - at $14.99 until the end of October you really can't go wrong!

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This game has a LOT of bugs. Driving through intersections your car reacts like it hit something. Your cursor can randomly get stuck. The ballistics make no sense, e.g. shooting at a vehicle window and nothing is happening.Gameplay is clunky, largely because of the horrible driving mechanics. Other commentors have said the driving is like Crazy Taxi; that is wholly accurate. There are some good parts of the game, but overall the game is repetitive and the flow of gameplay is hampered by the whole "stress" situation. This game would benefit a lot from a campaign, or at least set missions like in GTA. You need a car when off duty, but you only make like $500 a shift and your net income is more like $100 a shift after vehicle repairs (necessary due to aforementioned clunky driving and the fact that ramming cars is the only way to stop vehicles that do not pull over). The cheapest car is like $16,000. You can call taxis...but not to your house.So far I've been exploiting the bugs in the game to actually get any play in. For example, I quit after going off duty and then when I log back in I'm in my house, fully rested and fed. I also call my sister, who apparently drops me back at my house after we're done hanging out.There are so many elements of this game that just feel very amateurish and silly. I do not recommend this. Get LCPDFR, a mod for GTA IV.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												A great concept, but sloppy execution. Think of True Crime New York City; you could give tickets, inspect cars, frisk people, etc. However, like True Crime NYC, this game is rather broken. The world feels empty, the NPCs are nearly identical aside from a few color differences in clothing, there is a lack of dialogue. In all aspects, the game can be done if you look past these things but it really needs a lot of work. The aimming is clunky, the driving is dodgy, the weather effects are ugly. There is no denything that I still enjoyed the game. However, until the game is polished up, I will not be touching this game for a while. There are many ways the player can boost, or outright manipualte the way the game is meant to be played and quickly level up. Despite the bugs and exploits, you can have a fun time but the game can get really boring really fast, there's not much to do when off-duty. In conclusion, if you can look past the bugs and exploits, you will most likely like this game if you enjoy police simulators. However, if you are like me and suffer from strong OCD, the glitches will really drive you insane. If and when this game is a little bit more playable, I will indeed consider rewriting my review. Great concept, fun at times, but it needs a lot of work. 6.5/10.

Posted: October 31, 2016
												Enforcer: Police Crime Action is a good basic police simulator.  You are able to do some basic police stuff and you must take care of your player with food and comfort.  However, the game gets really old after a few hours of playing.  You are very limited with what you can do and the map is very unique.  When you enter a new section of the map, the game must load the new section as aposed to just continuing driving.  The bright side to this game is that it is compatiable with Mac users and it is the only realistic police simulator out there for Mac.  However, for PC users, I DO NOT recommend this game.  Instead, I recommend the LSPDFR mod for Grand Theft Auto V.  I know it is a bit pricey for the origional game, but trust me, it is a lot better then Enforcer.  I believe that Enforcer's price should be reduced to about $5.  However, the gameplay is not what makes me so angry.  It is the fact that the community wants to help the game by trying to give the developers ideas to make the game better, but the developers are not listening.  In fact, the developers have abandoned the game.  Everyone knows that this game has huge potential to become a major video game, but the developers have completly abandoned the game.  So do not try to give your ideas to the developers, because they do not care anymore.

												First I will start this review by touching on the admins of the game here on Steam. Quite frankly they are terrible with customer service, after asking a simple question one of their admins gave a short response (did not answer the question) then proceeded to lock the thread. Not the best way to handle a customer.The game itself has its high and low points. Despite what the designers state, it does feel a little repetitive no matter how you play the game. The limited customization of characters, the fact that characters don't have traits upon creation or their experiences working make the player character feel bland. The personal interactions are also very bland and don't do much to bring the player into the world of the officer they are playing.Enforcer does provide a large playing area where you can explore, yet the world feels a bit empty. In a day and age with so much attention paid to how Police Officers perform their job, you do not get any of this in the game. You do not even have other officers, events that change how the community sees the police, or a Chief that imposes training on the force.Unfortunately, it causes the game to feel a bit hollow. While you have the option to choose from a number of police vehicles, and freedom to patrol where you want, there's just a great deal missing that causes the game to not feel satisfying.  I am recommending the game only based on the fact it's the only one of its kind and it's not terrible if you have low expectations.The developers also should take a hard look at how they respond to customers as well.Of note, I definitely logged more than the six hours of game time it is showing.True Score: 5.5/10

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I do not write a lot of reviews, but I feel this simulator needs one. I'm not going to review the story line, but just the gameplay itself. Enforcer: Police Crime Action centres around a single municipal police officer in a small desert town. You respond to call the dispatch informs you about and you have the options to respond to the calls or not. There is also real-time events happening in the city as well. It likes to focus mostly around the every day duties of a police officer and it does this very well. The simulator also goes beyond the duties of a police officer and you have to maintain you social and home life when you are not on duty, like manage your stress, eating, sleeping, and spending time with friends and family. Now that I have vaguely explained the game, I'm going to go into pros and cons of the game.Pros:-The simulator/game, or whichever you prefer to call it, does an amazing job of immersing you into the life of a police officer. The lackluster graphics still do not get in the way of making you feel and believe you are the law enforcement of this town and tries to make you thorough in your investigations and arrests, making you feel like you want to make a difference in the one-cop-town.-The callouts. There is, at this stage of the game, quite a few different types of callouts that dispatch will give you while you're driving aroung town, looking for any law breakers. You can do simple things like, stopping some delinquents from vandalizing a public building to solving a kidnapping and finding the kidnapped and taking out the kidnapper and calling in an ambulance to take the kidnapped person from the situation.-The rank up system. There is a huge list of different ranks to go through, from just a simple patrol officer to the chief of police. The list is quite large and every crime you solve and even just giving an illegally parked car a ticket helps you earn points to rank up and earn new things, like different police vehicles and customization items to them, as well as making your paycheck at the end of each shift more bountyfull.-Being able to make vehicle roadblocks and checkpoints, for example, like creating a drunk driving program where you stop vehicles and perform breath tests to catch drunk drivers and even inspect vehicles to make sure they are road-worthy. Even just doing this can add enjoyment of feeling like a police officer and busting those damn drunk drivers a ticket and time in the slammer.-The game does balance the action and simulation very well. I have had to chase down many suspects that attemted to flee and deploy the tazer on them, watching them get the jitters and then give themselves up after one hell of a shocking. You are equipped with a pistol and a SMG when there are those times that you just can't take them down the nonlethal way. I found myself hiding behind my vehicle helplessly as the offender continues to sling lead my direction and found myself trying to figure out how to take him down and end the situation.I could name many more Pros to this game, but I may edit those in at a later time, but let's address the obvious Cons of this game now.Cons:-The graphics are horrendous, but given the small team that made this whole game themselves, you find yourself not caring too much, but this is a Con because the optimization is pretty bad. For a game that lack a lot of detail in the town there shouldn't be an excuse why I only get less than 20FPS on the medium settings on my system. The optimization is really bad and I run a pretty good system, so I should get 30FPS or more on the medium setting.-Physics are non-existing. You are, what feels like, stuck to the ground, like your car is a giant magnet and stuck to the ground. There's really not much else to say about the physic-less world, but let's hope there is some sort of physic engine added in later, probably much later.-The controls, oh the controls, they are awful, with no sensitivity sliders, or custom key options. You turn your car almost 90 degrees by just barely tapping the "A" and "D" keys. It makes it hard to stay to one side of the road and you find yourself all over the damn road and crashing into everything.-Damage system. Your car takes way too much damage easily. Just by bumper tapping or hitting curb, you'll find yourself repairing you vehicle up to 3 times a shift and the shifts are very short. To get to parking lots, or the gas pump, and the garage have no slope on the curb, so you always take a lot of damage by just trying to get into the gas station. It's extremely frusterating and annoying. This huge flaw needs to be addressed immediatley. Like, now, seriously. It almost ruins the game for me.-Your food, sleep, and stress bars. They deplete waaay to fast. I think they have been fixed, but they still go down way too fast. They need to be slowed down by 10x or more.Okay, so I hope this review helped people deceide whether or not to invest in this game. Is it worth $16 on sale? Maybe, but maybe not. If they release a MAJOR and I mean, MAJOR update soon. Then hell to the freaking yes it's worth it, but as it stands no. Helping this small team of developers is worth it, though. This game has AMAZING potential and I'm so damn excited to see what they have in store for this game. Personally, I give this game a 8.5/10. I love this game. The police simulation games come in a small amount, like Police Force 2 or the LCPDFR mod for GTA IV, so I welcome this game and I am happy to support the developers. Keep it up, so far this game has me hooked and I can't wait to see what you all have in store for this.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Enforcer is one of those games you have to take a chance on to enjoy. The graphics are bad, its really outdated looking for a 2014 game and the driving engine is handmade in Hell. However, the gameplay is there in spades - fans of Maxis' SimCopter will be at home here. You play a uniformed cop who simply works a shift and is faced with mundane tasks like setting up speed cameras to record speeding vehicles, or chasing down armed suspects after a botched home invasion. You can ask a suspect to comply while you check his ID, frisk him for weapons or arrest him, and use your radio to have him taken downtown or have his vehicle towed, all with an intuitive interface.The missions are quite repetitive and if you're quick to complete them, you can face a boring period of wandering around looking for speeders or drunk drivers while waiting for an "official" mission. However, if you like police themed games, Enforcer is not too bad.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I supported Enforcer during its infancy, when it was actually known as Police Tactics. The developers were friends of mine on a forum, and I eagerly expected the release. The trailers provided a great insight into what we could be doing when the game was officially released; however, it seems the actual product wasn't really portrayed very well. Enforcer: Police Crime Action delivers a fun and different experience with its gameplay:You have an off duty lifestyle, tied into the game with an actual need (Stress level). While it's not really superbly fun and you can't spend more than a few hours off duty before getting bored, it's a cool feature.Being on duty involves multiple 'tasks' in which you do not have to finish but increase your career points, leading to promotions. These tasks can be anything from pulling over a required amount of vehicles within a certain amount of time  to call-outs, robberies and drunks being just a few.Vehicle customization is a neat addition, offering four different vehicles (two are unlocked via secret codes, obtained by registering your game) all with their own liveries. Lightbars, light colours and wheel types are also some of the changeable options.To experience the features, you really must watch a gameplay. Of course, being a police officer, a day is never the same, and you have to watch someone play it to see this. Of course, as it's only a first release, bugs are to be expected, but this game has started very poorly. Driving needs a hell of a lot of fine-tuning, it feels clunky and not at all fluid. The entire game is sort of clunky; it plays very much the indie game it is. If you're looking for an LCPD:FR contender, you're not going to find it. LCPD:FR expanded on a triple A game engine, fully developed and rounded off by Rockstar; Odin Game Studio has built this game from the ground up and it stands as a completely different game. LCPD:FR has the advantage of calling in backup, more vehicles, an urban environment, backup, etc, whereas Enforcer is somewhat primitive in this approach, featuring no backup and only a crude radio to call in prisoner transport (this is executed via a loading screen), but I feel after many updates the realism will shoot up, making the game a more immersive experience than it currently is.The usual bugs are found, odd animations, cars flying everywhere, but these don't really affect gameplay too much (they did on the first release; gunfights were a mess!),, and provide a few laughs. It is a bit annoying, though.As it stands, Enforcer: Police Crime Action needs a lot of work, but if we do get that, it could easily be worth its £14.99 asking price.

content:
Posted: February 17
 Enforcer: Police Crime Action is a simulator game, and nothing else. The game has about 10-20 hours of gameplay, and is sorta fun until the moment when you realize that you have taken the same call 10 times. PLEASE NOTE: The development studio that made this shut down, your money will go into a bottomless pit if you buy this. PROS:Decent gameplay.Graphics are tolerable. (in comparison to JC3)It does get that simulator feel.Immersive enough (just enough) to be a little scary at times.Okay menu screen music?CONS:As i said in the intro, the game has very little variety. Even the shrubbery looks copy pasted.The story is utterly unnecessary, Simulators need no story. Take farming simulator. Do you need a story to understand what you are there for? Unless you can’t read, no. Same applies here.The game has been 100% abandoned by the developers. (The developers are abandoned too.) Unless you want a unfinished, unpolished game, DO NOT BUY [/b]The cut scenes are rendered in game, green region travelling walls and all.The NPC models.. Err, are strange…BugsThe scripting is strange.. When I was playing the game a little so I could make this review, I pulled a guy over for wrecking into a cement truck*, and randomly, after telling him he could go, he just randomly sprinted off and ran at a car furiously until I arrested him. *that wasn’t considered a crime, apparently.Some callouts are WAY too easy. I was called out to an injured person call, and I walked over, and called an ambulance, then it was over. No robbers. Nothing.One of the buttons while you are on duty does nothing that I can see (also, why a gun while off duty? I have never been attacked? Is that a thing?)In the game, it appears that you are the only cop in the city. Are you getting shot at by a gang? Tough luck mate. In real life, the entire city would come to kill them  if a single shot was fired at an officer, let alone 20! But in the game, you are the only person with a gun that isn’t trying to kill you!There is nothing stopping you that I know of from going and frisking everyone on the streets, farming easy points from the random illegal item system.  So much for the fourth amendment.In closing, It’s kinda fun, but unless you want a unfinished game, don’t buy.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												It's really not that bad. Let's just get that out of the way. Now, on to the review.This game needs some tlc for sure. The car physics aren't that great. They work, but don't expect GTA or Forza handling. The interface suffers from some flaws such as some wonky dialog boxes to choose actions, some odd "loading" type screens when taking certain actions that remove a car or an object from the world (such as towing a car or calling an ambulance) and interfacing with cars, drivers and suspects lacks useful feedback beyond a text message at the top of the screen. Some visual feedback would be nice, such as seeing missing/expired plates and/or defective equipment on the cars prior to a dialog-box based inspection once the car is stopped. It's a usuable system, but a complete overhaul to make it more intuitive and user-friendly would be a welcome change.The career system is lacking. I've yet to see any difference in the "ranks" beyond unlocking a new vehicle type. It would be nice to see it fleshed out more. Having to go "off duty" to reduce your stress level is an interesting idea, but lacks any depth beyond refilling a meter. Some more direct interaction would help it. The station serves little purpose except to drop off prisoners and request a "warrant" but I have yet to figure out what that even does.There's a currency in the game which is earned by working and can be spent on furnishing for your home (again, not a bad idea, just needs some work to makeit interesting.) Beyond appearances, everything seems to give the same stat boosts. Take the TV for example. The cheap and the middle priced TV both give an equal amount of stress reduction, negating the point of buying the more expensive TV. The other part which makes no sense at all is you have to pay for your own gas and vehicle repairs. I could understand repairs to a point, as you should be punished somehow for wrecking a squad car, but fuel? That makes no sense. Require fill-ups, sure. But no cop pays for fuel from his own pocket. The controls are functional, but again need thought out a little better. For instance, when ordering a suspect to stop, you have to use the "C" key. If you have your gun out, in order to fire, you first have to "aim" with a right click. I would remove the "aim" portion (since you should already be aiming if your gun is out) and bind the command function to the right click, so you can give orders quickly and still be prepared to shoot. Again, not a big issue, just an annoyance.So what is good about this game? All of it. It's a hell of a concept, with many underlying systems which make it all work well together. It's not perfect and it's a buggy mess, but it does have a certain allure and charm. The different styles of cruisers are really cool. Thee are several customization options once rank 3 is unlocked, including rims, paint scheme, lightbar type, and colors of each side on the lightbar. Once again, it needs more, but it really is a cool start.The missions can be repetative, but the constant stress of responding to a call and not knowing what you're walking into is really well captured. Sometimes it ends in a gunfight, sometimes they run then turn and shoot at you, and sometimes they just surrender or you really have to work at identifying which person is the right suspect. Again, it has it's flaws, but has potential. The biggest complaint I have is that there is always a suspect somewhere when given a call. It would be nice to occasionally find out no crime was actually comitted, but that would require a much more in-depth investigation system which I doubt this game would be capable of pulling off.Sometimes drivers pull over, sometimes a chase ensues, sometimes they bail and run on foot. Again, you never know what you will get. I can't commend this game well enough at mixing in the unknown to every contact with a car or suspect. It really is a good mix and keeps the game entertaining.If you want a perfect, AAA game with minimal bugs, tons of content, and bleeding edge graphics, then skip this title. However, if you enjoy finding hidden gems that might be a little rough around the edges, then definately give this one a shot. Have realistic expectations of what teh game is and is not and you will find it really enjoyable. Also, if you have younger children that are always fascinated with police, fire and ambulance vehicle every time they see one, then play this with them. There is no gorey bloody deaths, and while there is the occasional shootout, you still have to call an ambulance for the "bad guy" and be the good guy. For some with small children, it can be a good option instead of GTA and stealing cop cars.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												Well overall to summarise on this game, if you enjoy being a cop then go for it, especially if you havent played a cop simulator game before. As i got into it i was enjoying it, seemed quite new and refreshing, with placing speed cameras, traffic cones, stopping traffic, breathalising drivers, checking for damage etc. Then you got the missions that come up suddenly like theres been a report of a robbery so you have to investigate and catch the suspect(s).But so far into the game, this is pretty much all i've done. You start off as a police officer rank and work your way upto chief of police, and in the help guide in the game, it says as you progress ranks you unlock new missions and therefore take on more challenging and complex jobs. Yet this hasnt been the case, as i'm now a Lieutenant and i'm still doing the same jobs (getting the same jobs) that i've been given since the start and its now all too repetetive.So to sum up for me...i good game, different. But longetivity doesnt seem to be there for me, as i just keep getting the same missions despite having been promoted ranks and i'm now not too far off the top rank as lieutenant. Maybe someone else will back me up on this or reassure me that new missions do come up once you progress from lieutenant.Bit disappointing in this respect but a decent game. I'd recommend buying it when on discount.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Edit: keep in mind I made this review a decent amount of time ago, some of the problems have been fixed such as your car getting damaged while entering places like the gas station after the map was entirely redesigned, however many other problems mentioned still persistLet me start off by saying this game shows potential, however with that beign said, this game is not a finished product.The game has a number of problems that need to be fixed before it can truly be considered a worthwhile purchaseone of the first problems I noticed while playing the game is that, at least in the starting region, driving onto the platform for the gas station will damage your car, there is literally no way around this from what I have seen, this also occurs in other locations around the city such as the repair station (or whatever it is called). Furthermore the missions are often rather repetative as the criminals will often spawn in the same locations every time. In addition there is literally no incentive to bring the criminals back alive (if they have their gun drawn) you recieve the same points for killing the criminal as you do for brining them back alive (unless they dont have their gun drawn, points are lost for shooting at them).  As well despite the several distinct regions in the game, they all feel almost entirely bland as they are rife with either unenterable buildings, or land with nothing on it. Another thing that I must complain about is the fact that shooting vehichles does literally NOTHING, if you shoot at a vehichle it will not do any damage to the vehichle or the driver, also problamatic is the fact that if you shoot at a civilian vehichle, no points are deducted. Another problem is that if you simply quit and reload your game, your stress level will be reset and your sleep and hunger levels are also almost enitrely reset, which removes the necessity to take anytime off. There are also rampant glitches, such as the fact that the main city (or at least the one your house is in the region of) is rife with invisible potholes on the streets that will do damage to your car if you go over them at too high a speed and possibly even send your vehichle flying. As well I have noticed sometimes that there will randomly be vehichles just sort of floating in the air. I have also noticed that sometimes in the city various vehichles will run into each other for no apparent reason, maybe it is just the drunk drivers but I dont know.Overall, I think that if the problems with this game are fixed it could be a good or maybe even a great game, I really do like the concept of a game where you play as a police officer as it has not been done very often, however until they fix the problems listed and the many more that I probably didnt notice or think to write about, then it is not really a worthwhile purchaseUPDATE: they are improving the game however, so hopefully soon they will fix the bugs that currently plague the game

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												While I've seen more than a few rather negitive reviews on this game, I'd like to add to the growing pool of positive ones.This game lacks a certain polish -- it almost reminds me of the old GTA or Driver games, yet has a sincere charm to it. It's a great concept (as mods for GTA V such as LCPD:FR have shown with their massive fanbase), and this actually isn't a bad excution of it, while it needs some serious bug-hunting and polish, the potential is certainly there.Problems:1.) Days are way too short, you don't have time to do much, then your character is clutching his guts in agony while standing in the road.2.) Time compression is extreme, gas runs out, hunger sets in, and your character becomes lethargic all while driving to work.3.) Physics are non-existent, one stop light in particular sends cars flipping across the road, good entertainment value, but certainly immersion breaking.The good stuff:1.) I think a game like this has had a demand for some time now, while we've seen a few teasers over the years they've often turn to little more than a flash in the pan, unless you count the CoD clone SWAT games (police=FPS... wut?).2.) The game-play is rather straight forward, and the Sims-esque needs give you a break after putting the hurt on drunk drivers for a couple hours. I know after playing GTA V with LCPD:FR for a couple hours, I often got bored and started a massive killing spree -- no reason to do that here.3.) Options: car liveries, and player clothing. You have several asthetic options right off the bat, all of which seem to have had work and thought put into them.4.) The future -- I think this game will get the polish it needs, the devs are small enough to work with their potential fanbase, and although I haven't had look at the files yet, probably has a good modability factor.I know what you're asking and why you're reading this: "Red, should I buy this game with my hard-earned money?"Well, I really couldn't tell you -- while the potential is there, it isn't yet. Is it worth $20? Probably not.. not yet anyways. Do you have $20 you want to spend and help a small company along the way? Then buy it. But if you don't want to spend $20 just to see if you like it, then I wouldn't recomend it, you'd end up hating it like the rather harsh people who've commented before me because now you think you "wasted" $20 on "this". Give it a shot though, and keep an eye on it, I know I will.-RedHorizon

Posted: August 3, 2016
												Well, where can i start?I was excited to play this game and oh boy was it a disappointment.The graphics in the game a bearable. I mean they're not really good but it's good enough.The AI well they can be really dumb. I saw an ai standing on the hood of the car and the car was going at least 20mph. It was quite funny to watch. The AI have they're spasms but honestly it wasn't that much, so the ai are good for what they are.The missions.. Oh my god.. The missions are unbelievably repetitive. I would say after an hour playing the game you'll be really bored because the missions are repetitive, you go round stopping them to check their vehicle and you do that almost every shift. Yes, you get the odd occasion where you get asked to stop a drug deal but even that is boring. The reason why is because you only need two bullets in your gun to kill the drug dealers, those kind of missions go way to quickly. Overall the missions are a pile poo. Another thing is sometimes you don't even get those drug dealers, arrest a murderer and that get really make you just want to quit the game.The driving well not much to say it's easy and their is nothing wrong with it.I think other than that the game is good. There need to be improvements but apart from the poopy missions the game is good.IMPROVEMENTS:1: Being able to mark a point on the minimap2: Need a storyline and more interactive missions.3: Ai cops4: Fix the game all togetherWell, that has been my review on this game. I do not recommend this game at the moment, who knows maybe in the future this game good be fxied but for now i highly recommend you don't spend your money on it. I have already requested a refund so i shall be getting my money back and getting something a little bit more my taste. Anyway i hope this helped.

												I want to make this review short and sweet since this game is hardly worth my time to review, however I find it my duty as a gamer to ward off people hoping to buy this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥---------------------------------------------First off: It's plagued with bugs. Flying cars, glitching NPCs, falling through the earth, getting stuck in the ground or buildings, failing an objective despite completing it with flying colours, hell some objectives won't complete at all and you'll be stuck in a state of boredom limbo.Secondly: The game is horrendously boring, so far I've only experienced 5 different events multiple times, and 2 flavours of side activity. Most of the time will be spent mining trading cards or waiting for the off chance that you actually get given an objective that you haven't completed 50 times previously.Thirdly: The team has abandoned it completely. They are nowhere to be found except in their miserable fiefdoms, moderating their forum with an iron fist like a Cold War era Russian dictator. They don't listen to it's player base, they don't update their game, they break all of their promises and they have the *gall* to insult players with actual concerns, actual criticisms and actual desires to see this game completed.---------------------------------------------In summary, stay away from this mess, the game is broken and it won't be fixed and the development team are petulant children not deserving of a single cent from you.If you want a police simulator, you're better off getting the First Response mods for GTAIV or V.

												Ever since I heard about this game, I was very excited for it to be released. I bought it the day it came out, and I think it was worth the 15 dollars I spent on it, but maybe not the full price. At least not yet. The game still needs a lot of work, but I appreciate that the developers are working hard to fix all the issues with the game. I'm not sure how quickly it will be fully fixed, but when it is, this game will be really great. For example, I am still having issues with cars flying in the air, and a lot of pop in. I'll be driving down the road and sometimes objects will just appear right infront of me. This makes it almost impossible to drive through town without almost totalling my car each time. I also am still having a lot of issues with lag. If I was playing a game like Skyrim on Ultra I might question if my computer can handle it, but with this game, I'm pretty sure it still needs to be optimized for more graphical set ups. I have a quad core and radeon duel graphics, so I think I should be able to handle this just fine... Any ways, once all the issues are worked out this game could be a lot of fun. I'll still thumbs up it because I have faith it will get better!

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This game is about a police action simulator in a small city, mixing genres of action, adventure and RPG. The player control the life of a police officer in a sandbox world, taking many kind of missions and at same time try to develop his career, building a non-linear open story.Enforcer brings you a different concept about how you can play a third person police game. You, as a player, can choose between a man or a woman to build a career and earn ranks if you are up to the task.The players have freedom to do many actions, but they will also suffer the consequences, especially in their career score points which can enable new promotions or not.Besides random mission calls during 365 days of a year inside the game, the player can patrol and talk with every civilian roaming in Towns and rural areas. After finishing your job, you can go home and upgrade your house, buying new items and furniture, or even a new car. Take care of your family, this can also helps you to control your stress.Choose between normal and realistic modes where "permadeath" is activated.Drug dealers, drunks, speeders, kidnapping, house breaking and many more missions will keep you busy and alert. And don't forget to punish that drivers that parked at wrong places, shame on them.Community Rating6.2/10

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Let me start this review off by saying that this game has its quirks, but also has a peculiar charm that keeps making me come back to play it. While it has a lot of fun things to do, it currently is quite buggy, which the developers have promised to fix in patches, along with new features in the next few months. So here are the pros:- Has a fun concept; patrol the town and surrounding country looking for criminals or traffic violations.- Different dispatch missions; various calls like drunks causing trouble, robberies etc.- Multiple ways of catching criminals; tasers, guns, shout at them to surrender etc.- You can kick people's doors in an arrest them with a warrant (this is buggy at the moment tho)Cons:-VERY buggy and not very user friendly at the moment (probably fixable in patches soon though)- There's no backup system, so ATM you're the only cop in town-animations, drivng physics and pursuits don't really work properly.-tasers make people hover in the air for a minute (???)So overall, if you're a fan of games such as SWAT 4 and GTA 4's LCPDFR mod, i'd recommend you give it a try after a few patches. For the dev's first PC release, it's pretty decent, with a good graphics/sound options menu.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Keep in mind this is very early in the release in the game:The basics of the game are quite simple; you go on duty, you pull people over, and respond to calls. It is very simple for the sole reason of it is a sandbox game- you roam and do what you want. The controls are a little difficult to adjust to but after you get the hang of it you find it all the more fun. The games concept is amazing. For a small team of developers the game could not really be any better thus far. Although it is not "Next Gen" in terms of graphics (or conrols for that matter) does not mean it is a bad game.  Yes, the game has several bugs that are being worked on. The game has the potential to be the only one of its kind and excel in the market. After the update late last night (day 2), I can already see the major imporvements and fixes. As long as the developers keep their ears open to the community I do not see how this game could be beaten.
